quest_title: If \(P(x)=ax^{2} +bx+c\) and \(Q(x)=-ax^{2} +dx+c\) where \(ac\ne 0\), then \(P(x).Q(x)=0\)has at least
explanation_txt:
Let all four roots are imaginary.

Then roots of both equations \(P(x)=0\)and \(Q(x)=0\)are imaginary.

Thus \(b^{2} -4ac<0;d^{2} +4ac<0\), So \(b^{2} +d^{2} <0\), which is impossible unless \(b=0,d=0\).

So, if \(b\ne 0\)or \(d\ne 0\) at least two roots must be real.

If \(b=0,\)\(d=0\), we have the equations. \(P(x)=ax^{2} +c=0\)and \(Q(x)=-ax^{2} +c=0\) or \(x^{2} =-\cfrac{c}{a} ;x^{2} =\cfrac{c}{a} \) as one of \(\cfrac{c}{a} \) and \(-\cfrac{c}{a} \) must be positive, so two roots must be real.

explanation_plain_text:
Let all four roots are imaginary.

Then roots of both equations and are imaginary.

Thus , So , which is impossible unless .

So, if or at least two roots must be real.

If , we have the equations. and or as one of and must be positive, so two roots must be real.

quest_title: If by dropping a stone in a quiet lake a wave moves in circle at a speed of 3.5 cm/sec, then the rate of increase of the enclosed circular region when the radius of the circular wave is 10 cm, is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { Given the rate of increasing the radius } } \\ { = \cfrac { d r } { d t } = 3.5 \mathrm { cm } / \text { sec and } r = 10 \mathrm { cm } } \\ { \text { Area of circle } = \pi r ^ { 2 } , A = \pi r ^ { 2 } } \\ { \Rightarrow \cfrac { d A } { d t } = 2 \pi r \cfrac { d r } { d t } \Rightarrow \cfrac { d A } { d t } = 2 \pi \times 10 \times 3.5 } \\ { \Rightarrow \cfrac { d A } { d t } = 220 \mathrm { cm } ^ { 2 } / \mathrm { sec } } \end{array}\)

quest_title: In a capillary tube experiment, a vertical 30 cm long capillary tube is dipped in water. The water rises up to a height of 10cm due to capillary action. If this experiment is conducted in a freely falling elevator, the length of the water column becomes
explanation_txt:
Capillary rise (h) \(=\cfrac{2 T \cos \theta}{r d g}\)

\(h \propto \cfrac { 1 } { g }\)

In freely falling elevator, \(g\) is equal to zero so height of capillary rise becomes maximum.

The length of the water column will be equal to full length of capillary tube.
question_plain_title: In a capillary tube experiment, a vertical 30 cm long capillary tube is dipped in water. The water rises up to a height of 10cm due to capillary action. If this experiment is conducted in a freely falling elevator, the length of the water column becomes
explanation_plain_text:
Capillary rise (h)

In freely falling elevator, is equal to zero so height of capillary rise becomes maximum.

The length of the water column will be equal to full length of capillary tube.

\( T \equiv x + \sqrt { 3 } y - 4 = 0 \)

This intersects at positive axis at (4,0) (Put y = 0 )

So, the triangle's vertices are \( A(0,0), B(1, \sqrt{3} ), C (4,0) \). Also, the traingle is right angled at B.

So, \( \Delta = \cfrac{1}{2} \times AB \times BC = \cfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \times \sqrt{12} = 2 \sqrt{3} \)

quest_title: A body of mass 2kg has an initial velocity of 5m/s along OA is subjected a force 4N perpendicular to OA. The displacement of body after 4 second will be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{S}_{1}=\mathrm{vt}=5 \times 4=20 \mathrm{m}} \\ {\mathrm{a}=\cfrac{\mathrm{F}}{\mathrm{m}}=\cfrac{4}{2}=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}} \\ {\mathrm{S}_{2}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 4^{2}=16 \mathrm{m}} \\ {\therefore \mathrm{S}=\sqrt{\mathrm{S}_{1}^{2}+\mathrm{S}_{2}^{2}}=\sqrt{20^{2}+16^{2}}=25.6 \mathrm{m}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: In Thomson's method of determining e/m of electrons,
ans1_txt: Electric and magnetic fields are parallel to electrons beam
ans2_txt: Electric and magnetic fields are perpendicular to each other and perpendicular to electrons beam
ans3_txt: Magnetic field is parallel to the electrons beam
ans4_txt: Electric field is parallel to the electrons beam
explanation_txt: In Thomson's experiment, electric and magnetic fields are perpendicular to each other and both perpendicular to electrons beam so as to cancel out electric force and magnetic force and let the electron beam pass undeviated.
question_plain_title: In Thomson's method of determining e/m of electrons,
explanation_plain_text: In Thomson's experiment, electric and magnetic fields are perpendicular to each other and both perpendicular to electrons beam so as to cancel out electric force and magnetic force and let the electron beam pass undeviated.
ans1_plain_text: Electric and magnetic fields are parallel to electrons beam
ans2_plain_text: Electric and magnetic fields are perpendicular to each other and perpendicular to electrons beam
ans3_plain_text: Magnetic field is parallel to the electrons beam
ans4_plain_text: Electric field is parallel to the electrons beam

quest_title: S.I. unit of universal gas constant is
explanation_txt:
From Ideal gas equation,

\(R=\cfrac{PV}{nT}\)

\([R]=\left[\cfrac{\text{Nm}^{-2}\times \text{m}^{3}}{\text{mole}\times\text{K}}\right]=\left[\cfrac{\text{Nm}}{\text{mole}\times\text{K}}\right]=\left[\text{Jmol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\right]\)

quest_title: The binding energies of \({}_{1}\)H\({}^{2}\)&\({}_{2}\)He\({}^{4}\) aer 1.125 Mev & 7.2 Mev respectively. In the process, \({}_{1}\)H\({}^{2}\) + \({}_{1}\)H\({}^{2}\)\(\rightarrow\)\({}_{2}\)He\({}^{4}\). Amount of energy transferred is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned}_{1} \mathrm{H}^{2}+_{1} \mathrm{H}^{2} \longrightarrow_{2} \mathrm{He}^{4} & \\ \text { Energy transfer }(\mathrm{E}) &=4 \times 7.2-(4 \times 1.125) \\ &=24.3 \mathrm{meV} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: In Young's double slit experiment, the intensity of the maxima is \(\text{I}\). If the width of each slit is doubled the intensity of the maxima will be
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)The intensity due to each source is I\(_{1}\). So

\(\quad\)I\(_{max}\) = I = \( \left(\sqrt{I_{1}} + \sqrt{I_{2}}\right)^{2}\) = 4I\(_{1}\)

\(\quad\)If the width of slit is made double

\(\quad\)I\(_{1}\)\(\) = I\(_{2}\)\(\) = 2I\(_{1}\)

\(\quad\)I\(_{max}\) = \( \left(\sqrt{2I_{1}} + \sqrt{2I}\right)^{2}\) = 8I\(_{1}\) = 2I
question_plain_title: In Young's double slit experiment, the intensity of the maxima is . If the width of each slit is doubled the intensity of the maxima will be
explanation_plain_text:
The intensity due to each source is I. So

I = I = = 4I

If the width of slit is made double

I = I = 2I

I = = 8I = 2I

quest_title: A converging meniscus of refractive index 1.5 and radii of surface 5cm andn 10cm. The concave surface is faced upward andn filled with water then focal length of combination will be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \cfrac{1}{\mathrm{F}} &=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{g}}}+\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{1}} \\ &=\left(\mu_{\mathrm{g}}-1\right)\left(+\cfrac{1}{5}-\cfrac{1}{10}\right)+\left(\mu_{l}-1\right) \cfrac{1}{10} \\ &=(1.5-1) \times \cfrac{1}{10}+\left(\cfrac{4}{3}-1\right) \cfrac{1}{10} \\ &=\cfrac{1}{20}+\cfrac{1}{30}=\cfrac{3+2}{60}=\cfrac{1}{12} \\ \therefore & \mathrm{F}=12 \end{aligned}\)

quest_title:
\(Ca(OH)_{2} +H_{3} PO_{4} \to CaHPO_{4} +2H_{2} O\)

The equivalent weight of \(H_{3} PO_{4} \) in the above reaction is
explanation_txt:
The equivalent weight of \(H_{3} PO_{4} =\cfrac{{\rm molecular\; weight}}{2} \) (Here valency is 2 because only two hydrogen atoms are displaced )

\({\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \) mole wt of \(H_{3} PO_{4} \) = 3 + 31 + 64 = 98w

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} Eq-Wt=\cfrac{98}{2} =49\]

The roots are \(1 , e ^ { 2 \pi i / n } , e ^ { 4 \pi i / n } \ldots \ldots \) which are obviously in G.P. with common ratio \( e ^ { 2 \pi i / n } \)

quest_title: If the resultant of two forces of magnitudes P and Q acting at a point at an angle of \(60^{o} \) is \(\sqrt{7} Q,\) then P/Q is
explanation_txt:
\(R^{2} =P^{2} +Q^{2} +2PQ\, \, \cos \theta \)

\[\Rightarrow (\sqrt{7} Q)^{2} =P^{2} +Q^{2} +2PQ\cos 60{}^\circ \]

\[\Rightarrow 7Q^{2} =P^{2} +Q+PQ \Rightarrow P^{2} +PQ-6Q^{2} =0\]

\[\Rightarrow P^{2} +3PQ-2PQ-6Q^{2} =0\]

\[\Rightarrow P(P+3Q)-2Q(P+3Q)=0\] \[\Rightarrow (P-2Q)(P+3Q)=0\]

\(\Rightarrow\) \(P-2Q=0\) or \(P+3Q=0\) From \(P-2Q=0\)

\(\Rightarrow\) \(\cfrac{P}{Q} =2\).

Now,

\(\mathrm{Or}, \mathrm{t}_{2}=1 \mathrm{min}\)

quest_title: A concave mirror gives an image three times as large as the object placed at a distance of 20 cm from it. For the image to be real, the focal length should be
explanation_txt:
We know, \(m = \cfrac{I}{O} = \cfrac{-v}{u}\)

And, for concave mirror, when the image is real, m < 0 (negative; when the image is virtual m > 0 (positive)

\(m = \cfrac { f } { f - u } \Rightarrow - 3 = \cfrac { f } { f - ( - 20 ) } \Rightarrow f = - 15 \mathrm { cm }\)

\(\cfrac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{m}_{0}}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1 / 2}}}\)
or, \(\mathrm{m}=0.1\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{120}{24}}=3.125 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{g}\)
